title: Cary Grant’s Sprawling Beverly Hills Property Hits the Market at $77.5 Million
description: The late Hollywood star’s wife rebuilt their marital dwelling into a 15,700-square-foot mansion
author: Katie Schultz
excerpt: The wife of late Hollywood star Cary Grant rebuilt their marital dwelling into a 15,700-square-foot mansion
text: The late Hollywood star’s wife rebuilt their marital dwelling into a 15,700-square-foot mansionActor Cary Grant at his house office, in Beverly Hills, 1964. (Photo by Leo Fuchs/Getty Images)Photo: Leo Fuchs/Getty ImagesA Beverly Hills property steeped in Hollywood history has landed on the market for a hefty $77.5 million. Golden Age leading man Cary Grant was in the process of renovating his home on a roughly three-acre plot when he met his fifth wife, Barbara Jaynes (née Harris), in the 1970s, per the Wall Street Journal. The pair were wed a few years later and Jaynes joined Grant at his estate, inheriting it after his 1986 death. 15 years later, the late actor’s wife married her current husband, real estate investor David Jaynes, and they began the process of rebuilding the dated property to their liking. It is that luxe, remixed mansion that the Jayneses are now looking to offload in favor of something smaller.“Cary, even when he finished [the renovation], he said, ‘I should have knocked the whole thing down,’” Jaynes said of the home, which Grant bought for $46,000 in 1946—the same year that he starred alongside Ingrid Bergman in Alfred Hitchcock’s film noir Notorious. The old house, where Grant and Jaynes entertained the likes of Frank Sinatra and Gregory Peck, had low ceilings and obstructed the surrounding city and ocean views—two faults that the Jayneses set out to rectify when they demolished the home to rebuild the 15,700-square-foot contemporary-style sprawl that now stands in its stead. “We didn’t want anything to clash with the beauty of the view,” Jaynes explained to the WSJ. And so, she elected to outfit the six-bedroom, 13-bathroom estate with tall ceilings and glass walls, many of which slide open for indoor-outdoor living.Join NowAD PRO members enjoy exclusive benefits. Inside, the home features white oak floors and white walls throughout, a modern eat-in kitchen, a particularly spacious home theater, a wine room, a glam room, and a full gym.Not a subscriber? html:
The late Hollywood star’s wife rebuilt their marital dwelling into a 15,700-square-foot mansion

A Beverly Hills property steeped in Hollywood history has landed on the market for a hefty $77.5 million. Golden Age leading man Cary Grant was in the process of renovating his home on a roughly three-acre plot when he met his fifth wife, Barbara Jaynes (née Harris), in the 1970s, per the Wall Street Journal. The pair were wed a few years later and Jaynes joined Grant at his estate, inheriting it after his 1986 death. 15 years later, the late actor’s wife married her current husband, real estate investor David Jaynes, and they began the process of rebuilding the dated property to their liking. It is that luxe, remixed mansion that the Jayneses are now looking to offload in favor of something smaller.

“Cary, even when he finished [the renovation], he said, ‘I should have knocked the whole thing down,’” Jaynes said of the home, which Grant bought for $46,000 in 1946—the same year that he starred alongside Ingrid Bergman in Alfred Hitchcock’s film noir Notorious. The old house, where Grant and Jaynes entertained the likes of Frank Sinatra and Gregory Peck, had low ceilings and obstructed the surrounding city and ocean views—two faults that the Jayneses set out to rectify when they demolished the home to rebuild the 15,700-square-foot contemporary-style sprawl that now stands in its stead. “We didn’t want anything to clash with the beauty of the view,” Jaynes explained to the WSJ. And so, she elected to outfit the six-bedroom, 13-bathroom estate with tall ceilings and glass walls, many of which slide open for indoor-outdoor living.

Completed in 2022, the abode is wrapped in terraces looking out at the resort-style grounds, which boast a tennis court, a 52-foot swimming pool with a view of downtown LA, and a garden laden with white roses. Inside, the home features white oak floors and white walls throughout, a modern eat-in kitchen, a particularly spacious home theater, a wine room, a glam room, and a full gym.
